overview.title: Overview
bullets: RSI is a momentum oscillator that measures the speed and change of price movements.
It oscillates between 0 and 100 — above 70 is commonly considered overbought and below 30 oversold.
RSI helps identify potential reversals and OB/OS conditions across markets.

items.title: Calculation
items.desc: RSI is computed from average gains and losses over a lookback period (typically 14).

items.title: Overbought/Oversold
items.desc: Readings above 70 suggest overbought; below 30 suggest oversold conditions.

items.title: Divergence
items.desc: When price makes new highs/lows but RSI does not, a potential reversal may be near.

items.title: 1. Overbought/Oversold Trading
points: Buy when RSI crosses above 30 (exiting oversold) and sell when it crosses below 70 (exiting overbought).
Use confluence from price action or other indicators for confirmation.

items.title: 2. RSI Divergence
points: Bullish divergence: price makes lower lows while RSI makes higher lows.
Bearish divergence: price makes higher highs while RSI makes lower highs.

items.title: 3. RSI Trend Lines
points: Draw trend lines on the RSI itself to spot potential breakouts/breakdowns.
Combine RSI breaks with market structure for entries/exits.

limitations.title: Limitations
bullets: In strong trends the RSI can remain overbought/oversold for extended periods.
Choppy, sideways markets can create false signals.
